comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: That's probably meant to be Mrs. Charles DeLoosey Oelrichs, a prominent member of Newport society and a member of the Congressional Union for Woman Suffrage too. She married Charles DeLoosey Oelrichs (1882-1973), a stockbroker, in 1907, and they were divorced in 1921. They had one child, daughter Margery (aka Marjorie, aka "Bubbles"); maybe that's her in the photo. If it is, she eventually married Eddy Duchin, the bandleader, in 1935, and became mother to Peter Duchin (b. 1937). Marjorie Oelrichs Duchin died two days after the birth of Peter. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marjorie_Oelrichs en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eddy_Duchin en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Duchin

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
The Mrs. Oelrichs in the photo above does not appear to be the same woman who, in another Bain/LOC photo, also is identified as Mrs. Oelrichs. Perhaps Bain made an error in one of the identifications. Moreover, the daughter in the other photo (who does not resemble the girl in this one) is identified as "Margaret," not "Marjorie." Here is the other photo:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3931851782/in/photostream/]

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Indeed, Wystan, this woman and daughter look more like the mother and daughter in the pictured labeled as Mrs. Amos Pinchot. www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4037482176/ The daughter, in particular looks to be wearing the same hat.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: www.newyorksocialdiary.com/node/136306 has pictures of Gertrude Minturn Pinchot that look like this woman, but is mainly about her daughter, who was the actress Rosamond Pinchot. Pictures of Rosamond as a girl on the web page could certainly be this girl.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content:
The Oelrichs seem like a complicated family with a lot of same-named people; Margery/Marjorie Oelrichs, daughter of the Charles DeLoosey Oelrichs, was born after 1907, which would seem to make her a little younger than this child.   

I like the alternate identification--they do look much more like the Gertrude and Rosamond Pinchot in the photo swanq links to.  Not only the same hat on the girl--looks like it could be the same dress, socks, and shoes too!

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thank you all for your comments which have helped us correct the caption. We agree that the people in this image are probably Mrs. Gertrude Pinchot and her daughter Rosamond based on the similar Bain negative www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4037482176/ and the websites you have provided. We will change the title when we update the database.

comment.author: 51277565@N00
comment._content:
How were they related to Governor Gifford Pinchot? I visited his home, Grey Towers, when I was a child. Never forgot it!

I read about Rosamund in "Edie" (the biography of Edith Sedgwick). I believe the Sedgwicks were related to the Minturns.
